text:
What are the sorts of-- we're just really
scratching the surface of the questions
that we're trying to ask in terms of how we
can think more formally

about design. So I'll start off by
saying that this is not just my group-- this
is not just my work,

it's the work of my group. And so a lot of my
PhD students have been working on
these sorts of ideas,

as well as a lot
of collaborators that we've been working with. I've highlighted in green
here the ones whose work I'll

primarily be talking about
today and just wanted to acknowledge them before
I share their work with you.

So normally when I start
talking about robot design,

I go back to this idea of, well,
when I was doing my PhD at MIT, we had this dream of, well,
let's say in the future we want

to have this ability to
create a custom robot-- and you don't need to be
necessarily a robotics engineer,

but maybe you have this idea of
a robot that you want to create, in this case, this person has an
idea of maybe some insect-like

robot that they want to move
over this rocky terrain-- well, wouldn't it be nice if
rather than having every PhD

student here spend any years
working on designing this robot, we were able to create
computational tools that

allow these people to help--
that help these people to input robot specs, help them
to make design decisions,

really streamline the design
process so that they can very quickly then take their design,
fabricate it in real life,

and then use it in
whatever environment it was that they
were thinking of. And so the key is
really, well, what is

it that goes into this system? And originally
when we were trying to formulate these problems,
we were saying, well,

let's really try to
specify what is a robot? What is a task? And so we came up with
this way of describing

these systems, which is, well,
a robot, it has some geometry, it has some joints, it
has degrees of freedom,

it has some
controllers associated. These are all variables,
design parameters that are associated with this robot.

There's also this task that we
want the robot to accomplish, there's an environment
that we care about, that environment has
geometry, but it also

has physics associated with it. We care about particular
contact modes potentially. And then there's some
objective, some performance

that we want to achieve. And if we can write
all of this down, then well, the problem
of design is easy.

The problem is,
well, we want to be able to achieve this objective
over the space of robots

subject to some constraints. And then if we can solve
this problem, we're done. So how do we solve this problem?

And so during my PHD,
we were thinking, well, maybe one of
the ways that we can try to approach this
problem is through modularity.

Let's say, well, there are
these different robot components that we care about, maybe
we can create modules for each of these
components and figure out

when can we connect
them together, how do we then simulate
the robot in order to get

it to achieve particular tasks. And we said, well, this
part here is really hard, this task specification
is really hard,

so let's focus just
on legged locomotion. So we built this system here. We called it Build-A-Bot.

This is a modular design system
where you take these components

here, which we hand designed and
now you put them into this 3D workspace.

A user can come in
and change the shape, these shapes are
all parametrized. So we can keep track of their
geometry, kinematic constraints,

all of that. Users can drag in other
parts and connect these parts

together. And as they do that, we imposed
a grammar on this system that

said, well, if you're connecting
particular types of parts together, then that
implies that you're connecting them with
joints or you're

connecting them with motors. And there are certain
controllers or kinematics that are associated
with these structures.

And so in order to make sure
that this robot satisfies fabrication
constraints, well, we

need to keep track
of the geometry and also what the fabrication
plan is going to be.

And then if we
also want the robot to be able to achieve some
particular task, in this case, we said, well, just get the
robot to walk over this ground,

then we can simulate the robot
executing the particular gait associated with our grammar, so
in this case, very constrained,

and then tell the user
what is going to happen. So in this case, they're
attaching the different parts of the robot together and
then you'll see in a minute

the robot being simulated. But basically, if we can
modularize this design process,

then we can very quickly
provide the person with feedback as to how their robot's
going to perform and allow

them to make these design
changes while making certain guarantees on geometric
feasibility or the fact

that this robot
can be fabricated. And so this software,
we said, well,

it gives us the first step. And so we can take
these robots, we've shown that they
can be fabricated, but let's see what other
people do with this software.

So what we did was a couple of
years ago we took this software. And we brought it to ICRA,
which was very conveniently held

in Philadelphia at the time. And so we put a
booth out and said, well, everybody,
why don't you try

to get design a
robot that's going to go over this environment? We'll give you a
score, which is, well,

how fast you can
cross this finish line and we'll see what people do.

And we wanted to track
how people actually approach the design
process when they're given a task like this and a
system that looks like this.

So this we ran this study
with about 37 people.

37 people participated
ranging from undergraduates to professors to people in
industry, basically the people

that we could bother
in the exhibition hall to interact with our software. And we tracked all of
the different operations

that they took in the software
to see how they approached the design process. And so what you're
seeing on the right here

is what they did over time. And we looked at, well,
what time are they spending in the design phase?

What time are they spending
in the gate design phase? How much time are they spending
actually testing the robot and observed the sorts of
things that they were doing?

And then afterwards
also talked to them to say, well, what
was your thought process as you were going
through this design process?

And so this here is an example
of the sorts of actions that one particular user
took during the study.

And I think there are a
couple of observations that I wanted to make,
which is, well, we

tracked their score
over time to see how well the robot was doing. The max score that was
achieved during the study

was around 16, 20, I think. So this person ended up
achieving something pretty close

to the best score,
but started out with a design that was
not actually that great.

But one really interesting thing
that we discovered together

with Cristina Wilson, who works
in psychology at Oregon state, is that people really
seem to get into--

they really seem to zoom in on a
particular design very quickly.

And so if we look in
particular at these lines here, we have the part
added, how many times

they modified the
existing design, and how many times they deleted
parts in the design, which we think implies means that
they were changing their mind

about what was going on. And so there's a
lot of parts being added at the
beginning when they're starting with a new design.

They did one test where
they got medium performance. And then this part here
not so much happening

on the morphology
of the robot itself, but a lot of tuning happening
on the exact geometry.

And so what we-- this was pretty
typical for a lot of the users that were in the study.

And what we concluded was that
people go into these design spaces, these design problems. And well, what they're
doing is not really

solving the optimization
problem that I showed before. They're not saying, well, what
is the best possible robot.

Let me look at all the
entire design space, really think about all
of the robot parameters I can deal with, and then find
the best design that's going

to give me my functionality. But rather they really find
something that they think is going to work and
then they iterate

over that particular design. And I think those of you who are
designers and, and even myself,

that's the mode that
we use for design. And so after seeing this,
we step back and said,

well, what is it then
that we're actually trying to achieve with these
sorts of design approaches?

Because at the beginning when
we started on this study, Cristina had done a lot of
reading in the literature

and said, well,
actually what we've seen is that there's a difference
between novice and expert

behavior and novices tend
to have design biases and experts tend to be more
willing to explore the design

space and we did
not see that here. We saw really everybody just
zoom in on a particular design

and iterate on it. And what we thought was,
well, maybe then what we're trying to do with
these design systems

or when we design robots
is not actually come up with the optimal design.

A lot of people are
really just trying to get a design that works. And so this is related
to some of the ideas

that people have
been throwing out in the mechanical
engineering design

community for a
while, which is, well, what is the difference
between how we achieve-- how we think about
mechanical design or robot

design or design
in physical spaces and how we think about things
that are very modular like VLSI

or how we think about
computer programs, which are also very modular? And I really like this
sequence of papers,

one from 1996 and the
following one year after, 1997, where the first one is
this title that says,

Why Mechanical Design
Cannot be like VLSI. And the argument here was,
well, mechanical design

is really, really hard. The reason it's really
hard is because actually mechanical design is
inherently not modular sizable

in the way that VLSI
and computer programming is because you have all of
these mechanical components that

are interacting with
each other and when you change one
part, that affects the behavior of another part. And so inherently, we cannot
actually deal with mechanical

design in the same way that
we deal with electronics. And so you have to design
the whole system altogether.

One year later, there
was this paper here from Erik Antonsson, which
was called the potential

for mechanical design
compilation, which is basically the complete opposite viewpoint.

And this paper was actually
written in response to the first one
where they said, well,

there are things in
mechanical design that are very interconnected,
very interrelated.

And so when you
change one part, you do inherently
affect other parts. But there are also some
things in mechanical design

that are modularizable. And maybe the key to thinking
about mechanical design

or in my area of interest,
which is robot design, is figuring out what
parts of that design space

can be modularized. And there's another part way
at the end of the paper, which

is also that maybe also the key
to allowing us to use modularity

for these sorts of
design approaches is to accept that
sometimes when we take these compilation or
these modular approaches,

that the design that comes out
is not going to be optimal. And so as long as we can achieve
particular functionality out

of the design itself and we
can achieve something that's possible, well, maybe we're
willing to make sacrifices

on the other part for the
ease of the design process. So this has really been
an inspiration for the way

that we've been approaching
design and computational design for robotics in our lab.

This idea that, well, if we want
to make design more accessible and we want to make it
easier to achieve, actually

what we need to do
is not necessarily try to solve these really
big optimization problems,

but rather think about, how do
we simplify the design process and look at interactions
between components in a way that allows
us to, first, just

figure out what designs are
possible and then second, then take those ideas
and then figure out

what designs are practical,
not necessarily optimal? So that sets the
stage for the projects

that I want to talk about
today and really sets the stage for the title of
the talk that I proposed,

which was trying to link design
approaches to planning problems

where people have really been
thinking about these ideas, well, what is optimal
versus what is practical

when it comes to how we get
robots to plan around space? Now, we can also think about how
we do this in the design space.

So I'm going to start
then with a project that we started thinking
about a couple--

I guess three years
now ago now, where we said, well, let's start with
a very particular type of robot.

Let's start with
manipulator arms and let's not even think yet
about actuation.

Let's just think
about kinematics. And let's think
about, well, if I want to create an arbitrary
serial manipulator

arm, when is it possible for me
to actually construct this arm? At the time, we had
a very specific focus

on origami inspired design,
but I'll show you later that actually the
algorithm we came up with isn't necessarily
restricted to origami.

But what we said was,
well, all I want to do is make sure that if
I have a robotic arm, I have a particular kinematic
structure I care about,

I want to be able to
fabricate that arm. What is it that I
need to do in order to achieve this particular
kinematic specification?

And so in order to do
that, well, we said, well, the way that we're going to
specify these kinematic arms,

now the task specifications
are very clear, we're going to use
Denavit-Hartenberg specification, which is
probably the most popular way

of specifying robotic arms. So how many people
here are already

familiar with
Denavit-Hartenberg? OK, some people.

So the idea behind
Denavit-Hartenberg is that, well, actually
what I care about is not the full
structure of the robot,

but what I care about
is these axes of motion. So in this is a drawing of
a three-link manipulator

arm with three revolute
joints, so the cylinders are revolute joints. And the axis of motion is on
the center of the cylinder.

And if I want to describe
the kinematics of this arm, I don't actually care where
the joints themselves are, but I do care where
the axis of motion is.

And the axis of motion can be
described by four parameters. So the four parameters
tell me where

the direction of this axis of
motion and the location of that

axis of motion relative
to the previous frame. And so this allows me to
describe the kinematics

of this structure. And if you want more
detail than that, then Denavit-Hartenberg
have a really great paper

describing what exactly
goes into the specification. But what's interesting
here is that basically

this specification
tells me exactly where I want the axis of
motion to lie, but I

don't care where the joints are,
which gives me an extra design degree of freedom. So I can place the
joints really anywhere

I want that allows me to
make this robot fabric able as long as the axes
of motion are correct.

And so we said, well, how do
we go about then designing structures that are physically
realizable that achieve

these kinematic specifications? And before I tell
you the solution to this problem or our
solution to this problem,

I'm going to take a sidetrack. So the sidetrack that
I'm going to take is on path planning under
curvature constraints.

So many of you have probably
heard of Dubins path planning, or planning
for cars, or airplanes.

These are vehicles
that have been studied for a really long time in
robotics research that can only

follow paths with some
minimum curvature.

So if I want this car
to go from this position and this orientation to that
position, that orientation,

I can't take a
straight line path. I need to follow a
path that consists of curves, straight lines,
and then additional curves.

And back in the 1950s, Dubins
showed that in 2D, these curved,

straight, curved paths are
shortest length paths for these sorts of planning problems.

And in the 1980s, I believe,
then Hector Sussmann showed that

in 3D then these paths can also
be used to describe the sorts

of paths you would
take from starting 2D-- starting position to orientation
to ending orientations

and positions in 3D space. Now, what's really interesting
about these paths is that

actually these are paths that
robots can follow in 3D space, but they're also paths through
3D space that basically create

rigid transformations. So if I have a frame down here
and I have a frame up there

and I create a series of
physical objects that implements

these turning and
straight line paths, then what I get is not a path
that a robot needs to follow

in 3D space, but actually a
physical link that generates a rigid transformation that I
can use to create a particular

relative orientation and
translation between my starting and ending frame. And so we thought that
this could actually

be a way for us to approach the
problem of design of manipulator

arms because what this means
is that if we put a joint down here and a joint up there,
as long as we can calculate

and then create
this path, then we have an arm that's fabric able.

So what my student
did, Weishi Chen, was he designed, in this case,
origami modules that implemented

these different paths. So we have this
module here, which gives you a curved path
rotation, this module here,

which gives you a straight line
motion, and then additionally, other modules that
give you joint rotation

and joint translation. And the key now then to
designing a manipulator arm

is actually mapping this design
problem onto a Dubins path planning problem.

And as long as we can solve
this path planning problem and we can combine these
origami modules together to create those paths, then
now we have a valid arm.

So the key insight
to doing this then is that actually when we
choose a particular kinematic

specification and we
want, in this case, Denavit-Hartenberg
specification, which only gives us the axes of motion, the
joint locations themselves

are not necessarily fixed. And normally when we're
trying to design robotic arms

as mechanical engineers,
you try to take the joints and put them as close
as possible to wherever

the other joints
are so that we don't have any of this extra
mass or volume around. But in this case right now, I'm
going to say, we don't care.

So if I have my
arm, for example, and my elbow here has the
axis of motion down this line,

actually, for the
purposes of figuring out where my hand is going to be,
my end effector is going to be, it doesn't matter if
my elbow is right here

or if it's over here as long as
the axis of motion is correct. And so I can use an
extra degree of freedom

in order to be able to design
these sorts of manipulator arms that satisfy my
kinematic specification.

The reason I can do that
is because I can now pull from existing properties
that have been discovered

for Dubins path planning that
these paths can be calculated as long as my joints are
sufficiently far apart.

And so what I need to
do now is basically go through this process of
figuring out for every joint

that I want to connect together,
where should I place it on its axis of motion in order
to bring it into a location

where I can actually
route these paths? Then I can convert those paths
into these physical structures,

and then I can do
that iteratively over the entire
structure of the robot. And so here what you're
seeing is the process

of designing a spherical joint. So what we have is
these three joints here, which have axes of motion that
all coincide here in the middle.

That was the
diagram that you saw at the beginning of the video. And then these are the
paths that get automatically

generated through this
process of converting this problem into a Dubins
path planning problem.

Each of the segments
of this path here get converted into
the equivalent origami

pattern, which in this
case is a tubular pattern. So it can be either constructed
through folding or if you want

to print out 3D tubes on a 3D
printer, you can do that too.

But what happens is if
we take this pattern and then we fold it, then
we get a physical structure

that lies along this path. And you can see the revolute
joints in these three locations

if we draw where their
axes of motion intersect, it'll be right at the
center of this mechanism. So this here, it has the
exact same kinematics

as a spherical joint. Not to say that
this is necessarily

yet a spherical joint that
you would want to use, but what we've
shown is that it is possible to take these sorts
of kinematic specifications

and automatically generate
some version of a fabric able structure that would have
the correct specification.

So this process
here actually works for pretty much any
Denavit-Hartenberg specification

for serial chains. And we've implemented these
ideas all of the modules into a GitHub repo.

If you're interested in
designing your own manipulator arms or spherical joints or
whatever it is you care about,

you can download
this code and input your own Denavit-Hartenberg
specification and see what comes out.

So in this case, we
basically said, we just want a kinematic specification
to a fabric plan.

What are we going to
do with this result? Well, now that's
the second question, how do we actually think about
then when these sorts of designs

are practical. And so we decided that,
well, this idea, maybe we'll

try to use it in order to
design a quadrupedal robot. Sounds fun.

So what we decided
to do was say, well, we want to design
a quadrupedal robot. We want it to have eight joints
throughout the entire body.

In this case, this is
not a serial mechanism.

This is a robot with
four parallel legs. But actually you can break it
down into two serial mechanisms

by cutting the robot in half. And so the way that you can
then take the tree associated with the robot and
decompose it into chains

is we can find longest
chains throughout this graph. And so now what
I need to do then

is if I want to design
a fabricable version of this robot, I need to design
the kinematic chain associated

with the body and
then I also need to figure out all of the
actuation control, everything else associated with it.

So this part here presumably
is now relatively complete.

I need to figure out where the
joints are that I care about, and then I need to design
this fabrication plan.

The key now is, how do I make
this whole structure more compact in order to make this
robot not really unstable,

but still allow me to
input all of my actuators? And so the way
then that we start

thinking about this
problem is we can still build on the insights
from designing arbitrary kinematic chains
I showed you before,

but now we also need to take
our actuation into account. Our actuation
effects two things.

It affects the volume of space
that this actuator is going to take up and actually
the joint location affects

how much torque it
is that the motor is going to need to produce,
which then affects its volume. So the volumetric
constraint is not too bad.

Actually, since we are already
treating this problem as a path planning problem, what we need
to do is route these links

through 3D space while avoiding
whatever space the motors take up as if they were obstacles.

And so these sorts
of paths can now be generated that allow
us to place these motors.

At the same time, the
torque requirement imposes length constraints. And so now what you can also
do is instead of arbitrarily

placing these joints in 3D space
in such a way that these paths can be routed, we can add an
optimization on top of that

allows us to make everything
as compact as possible while satisfying all of the
constraints associated with

routing Dubins paths. So if we do that, then we get
a chain that looks like this.

This chain here
has the kinematics that we care about for the robot
that we're trying to build, but it also has
space in there for us

to mount all of the actuators
that we've specked out to produce this robot. So what you're
seeing now here is

the resulting
quadrupedal design. This is a body that has been
folded by hand, by [INAUDIBLE].

The body of this
robot though has been designed through
this algorithm

that I showed you previously
where he basically specified exactly where he wanted all of
the joint axes of motion to go

and then folded this and then
put all of the motors on. This is the robot walking.

And then what you're
seeing here is us also trying some more
dynamical gaits, the robot

bounding or in this
case-- yeah, bounding and being able to withstand the
forces and torques associated

with creating these maneuvers. I will say that this is
actually the fourth iteration

of this robot that
you're seeing here. The first iteration that
we designed-- we actually

forgot to leave room
for all of the motors that we would need
to put on top. And so when we
she tried to mount

all of the motors and
electronics, none of them fit. There were huge collisions. It didn't work. But then we were
able to add in all

of the extra additional
constraints associated with routing these paths
around the motor volumes

and what you're seeing
here is the result. So these robots
here, then we've been

able to take advantage
of our algorithms for generating these
bodies to iterate over

the design within a
few days at a time. So between the
first version, which couldn't take any motors on it
at all to the second version

was about three days. And then after that, every
time we run the robot

and we notice an issue,
oftentimes material fatigue, then we can iterate over the
design within another few days

to a week.  So this now allows us to
think about these sorts

of kinematic designs
without really thinking about the fabrication
specifications other than the material.

So to compare this robot
then to existing quadrupeds, this one here on the
right is the mini cheetah,

the one on the left is ours. We call it the dynamic origami
quadruped or DOQ for short. The mass is much lower
because in our case,

we're building everything
out of thin shells. And the degrees of
freedom are also lower because we
decided we didn't

want to go for the full
12 at the beginning. But in terms of size and
capabilities that we have,

they are pretty similar
to existing quadrupeds that other people have built.
So any questions so far?

I guess I'm just curious,
how did you incorporate all of the force and
power constraints into the kinematic specification
to make sure it doesn't collapse

under its own weight? Sure, so the force and
torque constraints, which I really
glossed over here,

I guess they're two
different types that we need to think about mainly.

One of them is the
actuation torque and the other one is
forces on the robot body

that will affect its ability
to withstand the weight of all

of the other components. So for the second one, I'll
talk about that in a minute.

In this case, we just assumed
that all of our rigid tubes were actually rigid. For the actuation torques
basically what you can do

is take a look at
families of motors and their scaling
laws associated with families of motors.

And so if you know what
the torques are associated with moving particular
components of your robot

because what the mass
distribution is, then you can take those resulting torques
and then use them to figure out

the size of the motor
relative to whatever your initial
specification was and then

we use that to then design
the kinematic structure, yeah.

But the question about structure
then becomes really interesting because one of the other parts,
things that our lab cares about

is compliance. And you might notice
that on this table here,

I did not say anything about
cost of transport, or energy consumption, or how much work
these motors were actually

doing. In our case, because this
robot is very, very floppy,

because these rigid components
were not actually rigid,

we wasted a lot of energy. The cost of transport
here is probably about 10 times what you might
find on a commercial platform.

And so from there, we really
started to think about, well, how do we then start
design with the compliance

of the structure in mind? How do we think about the extra
flexible degrees of freedom that might be in this robot?

And how do we tune them to give
us the sorts of deformation that we care about?

So for this problem, we went
back, again, to manipulator arms and we started thinking about,
well, if we have a say now,

a tubular structure that
is actually compliant, it's not rigid the way
we were assuming before,

how is this structure
going to deform? And the way that
we started to think about modeling these structures
was as networks of springs.

This is a generic
model that you could use for our origami
robots, but also

for many of the soft robots
that exist in the literature right now. And if we think
about these springs,

then tuning the stiffness
of these springs gives us different deformation
modes for this robot.

So what you're seeing
on the right here is a version of this
three segment platform that we built where actually
the stiffness distribution

throughout this
structure is not uniform. So if I take a tendon
and I pull down

the center of this
platform, the softer springs are going to compress
first and then the stiffer springs
are going to compress.

And the way that this
structure deforms is going to depend on the
stiffness distribution. This is a really
abstract version

of what was happening
on the legged robot that I showed you on
the previous slide where actually in that case,
the stiffness is dictated

by the particular geometry
of the fold patterns that we care about. But we start with this
particular abstraction

because it allows us to
think about the structure in a little bit easier way. So the way that this
structure then deforms

depends on the energy landscape. So if I'm pulling the
string this slowly,

then this whole
structure is going to tend to bend in the
direction that brings it to a state of lowest energy.

And what we did was that
for these particular types of tubular structures, we can
construct stiffness matrices

associated with them. But those stiffness
matrices have a particular structure in them.

And so actually, for
structures like this, the tubular structures
that we've been designing,

the way that these robots deform
has an analytical solution.

And so we can construct these
matrices associated with kv,

these are the stiffnesses
that each of the springs. Here we have theta
v is basically

the ID associated with springs
along the circumference of this structure.

And v is the number of springs
around the circumference of the structure. And then the way that this
structure then deforms

is dictated by basically
this matrix equation. So what that means
is that actually

if I have this solution,
then I can use it in order

to figure out which
direction the structure is going to deform when
the stiffness changes. I can find energy gradients
in this energy landscape

and I can manipulate
those gradients in order to get the structure to
tend to a particular new pose.

So what we found is
that what we can do is use gradient
descent-based approaches very

similar to potential fields and
potential planning approaches. Basically we're getting
these structures

to move along these
energy landscapes and tune the local minima
of these energy landscapes

so that the deformation is
the one that we care about. What we do here is not
change the lengths of tendons

or actually DC motors the
way you might normally think of in traditional
rigid robotics, but what we're
thinking now about here

now is stiffness change. And so these correspond
to material properties that are associated
with the springs

throughout the
structure of the robot. So if I take this
idea and I say, well,

what I'm going to do is now
assume each of my springs is an actuator, and let's say
that I want this manipulator now

to bend in a particular way
for this particular scenario, I want it to be such that when
I pull a tendon down the middle,

the whole structure
is going to deform and the robot is naturally
going to get its end effector

to this purple triangle. I can do that by
manipulating the stiffnesses of these springs.

So what you're seeing
here in this animation is each of the thicknesses
of these springs here corresponds
to its stiffness.

This robot here is basically
just following gradient descent along in order to
update those stiffnesses

and get this robot to
deform into the right shape. Once this happens, I can now
take this stiffness distribution

and use it as part
of my design if this is a particular deformation
that I care about. What's really interesting
is that if I'm

modeling these soft
robots in this way, then I have a lot of extra
degrees of freedom actually.

And so this robot here, I
can get the whole structure to deform so that it
curves and the end effector

hits this purple triangle, but
I can also then uniformly scale all of the stiffnesses so that I
can achieve these configurations

with greater stiffness
or greater softness. And so actually since the
system is now over actuated,

I can use these extra
degrees of freedom to tune the stable
configuration and the strength

of the robot at the same time. So these sorts of
ideas I think really highlight the way that
our lab is now headed,

which is to think about how
these sorts of design problems can be cast as also
these planning problems.

And I can take these sorts
of ideas where I say, I want these robots to follow
gradient descent in stiffness

and implement them either
in real time, which is what you're seeing
here where we designed these electromechanical
actuators to be able to tune

stiffness on the
fly or we can take the results of these
sorts of approaches

and then implement them
onto fabricated systems. What you're seeing there
is the same system,

but without the motors. And so that when you change
the stiffness and then it deforms in a particular way,
in this case an s-shaped curve.

So those are the sorts of ideas
that we're now starting to think

about in terms of, how do
we think about these extra properties of the robot-- these
sorts of material stiffnesses

as an example-- and treat them as actuators
potentially, or actuator able degrees of freedom
that now allow

us to take advantage of existing
approaches to do design, or if in the future we manage
to get these tunable stiffness

actuators to be smaller and
more compact, or for planning? So in this case, I talked
about material stiffness,

but I wanted to take
these last few minutes,

I believe, yes, to give
you a preview of where we're taking this
work in the future

beyond just body robot design. So these sorts of ideas work
not just for soft robots,

but we've started to learn that
they allow us to start thinking about how robots also
move on compliant surfaces

or how we think about the
compliance and the robot combined with the compliance
of the environment.

So what you're seeing here
is videos not from me, these are videos from Feifei
Qian at USC and Doug Jerolmack

at UPenn of a commercial
quadrupedal system, using its gait that
it comes with to try

to walk on a sandy environment. What happens here is that
the sand is very compliant.

You're seeing it's kicking
up sand every time it walks. Depending on how much
compaction the sand has,

the robot is feeling different
forces coming from the ground. And when it gets to a
particular type of ground,

it can't handle it. The way that the ground deforms
makes the robot go unstable

and it flips over. At the same time, these
folks have found out

that actually you
can use signals from the motors in
these robots in order

to detect ground forces
as the robot is walking. So what you're seeing
here is another video

from Feifei's group where she's
just having this robot now walk in white sands.

And as it's walking, it's
recording the currents coming in at the motors and
converting those currents

into forces. At the same time, this robot
is tracking the positions

of all of its joints
so it can also figure out how much the toe
is intruding into the ground. And what you get are
forced displacement curves

for the robot's foot into the
ground that look like this. And so actually these
sand-like environments

look a lot like springs. And so once Feifei
and I were talking,

we said, well, actually this
is a really interesting way to then think about
robot interactions

with compliant grounds if the
compliance are very spring-like. And the way that we can
model these sorts of robots look very similar to the
segmented manipulator arms

that I showed you before. In this case, now
we have a rigid body that is the robot's body itself,
legs, which you can control,

to act like springs through
PID controllers and springs, which represent
the actual ground.

And so we can try to figure
out how to tune these material

properties in order to get the
robot to be able to walk stably over these sorts of surfaces.

So this was the start of
a new project we recently started in November that
we're very excited about.

This is a project that is
part of NASA's luster program that we lovingly call TRUSSES.

It stands for
Temporarily Robots Unite to Surmount Sandy
Entrapment, then Separate.

The premise behind this
idea is that robots now can take advantage of their
sensing to detect interactions

with the ground. In order to do that
or when they do that, they get a sense of
these ground properties

and they get a sense of
how compact the ground is and what will
happen when they try

to execute particular walking
maneuvers on this ground. And then based on
that information,

we can design
configurations for robots that allow them to navigate
over these environments more

reliably. So the underlying hardware
behind these systems that we're going
to be working with

is the spiral zipper and
the variable topology truss that Markham is
working on at UPenn.

And the idea is that then
we can take these trusses and we can connect
robots together in order to create
these sorts of networks

where the robots don't
necessarily just have the interactions between
their legs and the ground, but they can also apply
forces to each other

to create lateral
motion if they need to, to resist particular
types of instabilities. So the idea is then we
can take all of this work

that we've been thinking
about on the material property side and the
physical design side and now use them to
also come back and do

that are trying to move it
around in this environment.
